text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Lieutenant-General Phaedon Ghizikis, "President" of Greek junta in 1974, admits he issued orders for overthrow of Cyprus President Makarios during coup that July. President of parliament Spyros Kyprianou appeals to Greek government to have Ghizikis arrested for alleged crime.
- Communist Akel decides to support independent George Iakovou's bid for presidency.
- Nicosia municipality lists 111 buildings to be protected from demolition in walled part of city.
- U.N. and foreign mediators confident Turkish Cypriot leader Denktash will attend second round of U.N.-sponsored talks in Montreux, Switzerland, later this month.
- Trade unions threaten strikes in seven large hotels in Larnaca, Paphos and Ayia Napa unless employers acknowledge existence of collective working agreements.
- Ankara takes another step towards supporting breakaway
Turkish Cypriot state by making it self-sufficient in electricity.
- Mismanagement in cooperative credit societies relating to accumulation of bad debts could cost them millions of pounds.
